review: after a few days I realized this was a bad call? poor support help, poor selection of  covers and keyboard options, screen rotation is half and half touch response is still iffy??  overall I would never buy this product again. it does have good download speed great color and sounds pretty good, but for the price??
Best combo of screen (1280x800 IPS), OS (5.1), Memory (32) for the price! Needed GPS and sometimes hard to find 10in with GPS.
Very good tablet works well good quality.  I would definitely buy again.

Won't replace my iPad but definitely worth the price. I bought this tablet for my children. When I first got it and tried to connect it to my Wifi I had a bunch of issues. I think the signal strength of this tablet isn't the best. Once I got the range figured out I just made sure to stay in said area to download or play games that require wifi. I want to note I even have a wifi range extender so the issue shouldn't be on my end. Minor issue so moving on. It comes with a screen protector on it so that's is a great plus! No worrying about applying it or finding one to purchase. I'd gave to say that I don't feel the button layout is very user friendly. I find it to be akward and not very well planned out. Overall this is a good tablet for the price. In the box it comes with different outlet adapters for travelers or those who live abroad. I feel at a price point of $100.00 it is worth it but not over $100.00. I recurred thus product at a discount in exchange for an honest unbiased review.

You can do a lot of things in this tablet.  It has a lot of storage space.  You can save a lot of pictures and  It is easy to set up.  The user manual is easy to understand. You can play games, watch movies, use as GPS, etc.  Most of the time we use this to play games and watch movies that you can set this to a Super HD player.  This is a good tablet - it is fast and runs well.  It is lightweight and thinner.  Screen protector is already pre-installed.  I will do an update on this tablet's longevity.  I got this on discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I was looking for a nice and large (10"+) tablet, which will not break my bank and still has great features. I was really happy to be offered this 10.1" Fusion5 104 GPS Android Tablet PC at discount in exchange for honest and unbiased review. First of all, it is a well-rated product in UK (my guess they launched it in UK first) - 10.1" Fusion5 104 GPS Android Tablet PC - 32GB Storage - Android 5.1 Lollipop - Bluetooth 4.0 - FM - 1280*800 IPS Screen - 5000mAh battery - 2MP front and rear camera - Supports OTA Updates. So it wasn't as scary to purchase it. :) PROs: - PRICE. When I purchased it it showes $149.99 (really nice) and now it shows $99.99, which is even better! I mean over 10" tablet for under $100? What's there to think about? Comes with 1 year warranty! - SIZE. 10.1" elongated (kind of like widescreen) - STORAGE. 32GB. Definitely awesome! Many tablets come with 8 or 16 GB. I really feel that nowadays with all the applications/games, 32GB must be a minimum. I have few other tablets at 8GB and 16GB - the memory ran out pretty fast. And on top of 32GB in this tablet, you can get memory card to store even more! - PORTS. Micro SD Card slot (up to 64GB). Also has mini HDMi output (you can connect to TV!). - CAMERA. Dual camera (front and back). Both 2.0MP. - SPEAKERS. Dual speakers (you get a good stereo sound) - ACCESSORIES. Nice feature that it has power supply with interchangeable outlets for few countries (Europe, US, Australia) - PACKAGING. Very appealing box it's coming in, which is also important, if you are giving this as a gift. CONs: - CASE - I wish more cases were available or maybe generic cases would fit. When I emailed to the seller, he suggested me this one - 10.1" Fusion5 Folio PU Leather Case Smart Fit Cover For Fusion5 104 GPS Tablet Only. I have little kids and looking for a Shock Proof case, something like this one - Pwr+ Samsung-Galaxy-TAB-4-10.1-inch Case-for-Kids Protective-Sleeve-Cover Pink : Guardian KickStand with Handle for Samsung Galaxy TAB 4 Kid Friendly Shockproof Light Weight Tablet Tab Stand. Some of you will want a pretty case, other than plain black.. lol :) - SCREEN PROTECTOR. Already pre-installed. Yes it's nice thinking, but it does bubble up. - ACCESSORIES. Put a mini HDMi cable. The tablet has a port, so it's nice to add this cable. I think it's about time a nice large table cost under $100.. Lol.. I will post updates on its longevity... ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- UPDATE: MAY 2016. The screen got broken. Not sure how - started at the angle. But that's not the problem. The problem is we have installed many Digitizers ourselves for iPads and Androids, so I was hoping I can get a Digitizer and simply change myself. Here is the response I got from seller: "Hi. Thank you for your email. We are sorry to hear of your misfortune Unfortunately as warranties do not cover accidental damages, it would incur you a cost of $59.00 for replacement screen repair. (This quote includes labour, parts and return postage from our repair centre) If you are unsure about it, we suggest you to take a third party independent advice. " So, there are no Digitizers for this device and I need to pay over $60 (s/h as well), so they can repair the device?? Stick to the famous brand names, with less hassle.

I was searching for a new, faster android tablet for under $150. This tablet is pretty fast, has a bright screen, good color quality, and one of the best features is it can accept up to 128 gigs sd mini card. It's everything the item description says it is, and then some. If you get a mini card for it, you'll want to get at least a Class 10 HD, which I plan to do in the very near future. Its manual states that it will accept up to a 32 gig external card, but in the description that Amazon puts out, it says that it will accept 128 gig card. I talked with Amazon about the confusion. After Amazon checked, it was confirmed that the HD Model will accept the 128 gig mini card. I don't know about the lower-end models, but the HD model will take the 128 gig card. This is a very impressive tablet, especially for the price, and I am quite pleased with it. Battery life of 5 to 6 hours is a little disappointing, but I can live with that. After all, it is an HD Model. The cameras are kind of low-end, but I can live with that too. Overall, this is an exceptional tablet for the price!

You get what you pay for with this.  It freezes all the time.  It randomly restarts all the time.  It runs through every app installed saying it's not responding.  This thing was freezing right out of the box.  Definitely disappointed with this purchase.  Spend a little more money for a Samsung.
Very cheap supposed to be 32 gigs was only 16 gigs. Takes about two minutes to turn on. Then my apps keep shutting down for no reason.

The performance makes this tablet is impractical for normal use. My android phone (pixel xl) ran more than 15x faster than this tablet. It took 7 min to download a route for my Rideshare bike app on my phone and this tablet was a 1hr 45min into the download (73%), when I left the tablet to finish.
That speed difference seemed pretty representative of the power up of each device, internet surfing, running apps, etc. The large number of 5 star reviews makes me wonder if my unit was defective.

I bought this tablet to replace a worn out ASUS Memopad, which I thought was pretty good, but this new tablet is awesome!  Many apps that I used on my phone wouldn't work on it, but I've yet to find one that won't work on my new Fusion5.  I can watch Netflix and Amazon Prime (prime app wouldn't work on my ASUS) and even show them on my flat screen or projector using the mini-HDMI port (the cable from my ASUS even worked with this one, bonus!)  The screen is beautiful and clear, and the tablet is very responsive.  I can't find anything I don't like about my new Fusion5, 10 inch, Android 7 Nougat tablet.  If you are in the market for an Android tablet, don't pass this one up!
Loving this fusion 5 tablet . It has amazing graphics. Light weight and is just what I wanted. Thank you!
Nice tablet. Use it for a gps. Fast shipping good customer service. It performs so well I bought an other for the wife.

This tablet is a middle of the road product that shows you get what you pay for. It is a perfectly fine tablet for the price. $99 will not get you super high quality anything in the electronics world

It is not fast, but it will play most apps at a reasonable speed. Graphics and sound are adequate and with a little tweaking it is serviceable for most duties. Just keep in mind it is only $99 so it won't blow you away in any way.

It loses a star in rating because it is difficult to find a cover for it and screen protectors don't stay on properly. But then again, I don't feel the need to super protect a $99 tablet.

Screen has held up for me after minor wear and tear. It is a little awkward dimension wise but not a big issue.

So if you need a cheap tablet to do a bit of surfing, play a couple mid-level Apps, and do minor functions this tablet does its job.
I love it.  Works great, exactly what I wanted.  I also enjoy the fact that there are ports when other tablets don't have them.

Ordered this for my wife's birthday, and we all love it. Great graphics, good speed. The only draw back is the lack of a magnetic sensor, you can't use a compass on this machine, but that is a minor fault. I would have bought a fusion5 with the sensor if I had known. I would buy another one.

This is my second Fusion 5. My dog damaged my first one, but I liked it enough that I replaced it with the same unit. I got the 1920 x 1080 version, for $10 more it's a no-brainer to go hi-res. Bluetooth work fine with my headset. Battery life is really good, lasting through a couple movies on a 3hr flight with some still in reserve.
This tablet is easy to set up and runs Nougat. The 32GB is enough for me. It is not blitz-fast, but streaming video works fine.

I've never written a bad review before. I bought it to take traveling to do basic surfing with a screen larger than my phone and because my 5 yr. old slow-as-dirt chromebook couldn't download the map.me app I needed.and to read e-books on.

The good things are that it looks nice.  The build is nice, the screen is great, the sound okay.  It looks great for the price.

The bad thing is that it's slower than dirt. Google Play and google are always freezing and the internet connection is terrible.  Yesterday I opened up last pass to send a video link from facebook via email.  Typical and simple, right?  It took 40 minutes and I wanted to throw the tablet at the wall.  I got out my old chromebook (which I now think is screaming fast in comparison) and the same sequence of actions took about 10 minutes from the same wifi location.

So I don't know if the modems are awful on these tablets or if I just got a lemon.  But I'm seriously NOT happy with it.

It just arrived today. It came in a very nice-looking, sturdy box, with a charger and charging cable.
I like the fact that it uses a standard USB connection, so I can buy replacement cables anywhere. The last low-cost tablet I got had a weird plug, and I was always loosing the charging cord.
Now when my niece (the tablet is for a kid) needs to charge it up, she can use any of the half-dozen or so chargers strategically located around the house.

It came with a manual, but the text was small and light and unreadable. But you don't need it -- turn on the tablet, sign in to your Google account, and just go through their prompts. No problems at all, and I got it set up the same way I had it on her old tablet.

The manufacturer did include a note that said I would get a gift for writing this review (a fidget spinner, a power bank, or a micro sD card) so take this review with a grain of salt.

I use a Samsung tablet as my main tablet, and this one feels a little bit slower. But that could also be that I'm in the process of re-installing all the odl apps. (You go to the Play Store, pull up "my apps" and just select all the ones you want to reinstall.) And there were a couple of times when Google Play stopped responding and I had to start over, but that could have been because I was juggling several accounts -- mine, my sister's, my niece's, and a restricted profile for my niece, since she's very young.

But I can definitely see using this if my own tablet isn't available.

The biggest problem I had with this tablet is that I had trouble finding a screen protector and case to fit. It was slightly shorter but wider than the previous tablet she had.

I ordered the Fusion5 104A GPS Case, and it didn't close tightly.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01KI3AWMO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The case was too wide and too short (or vice versa -- the case was a thinner rectangle and the tablet was more square-ish). I'm going to have to order another case. I'm having trouble finding one.

And I ordered the Dmax Armor [3-Pack] for Insignia Flex 10.1 inch and had to cut it to fit -- it was too long.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01B6SLAOE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

UPDATE TWO HOURS LATER: It's done installing all of my niece's old apps and updating software, so I went in and starting customizing the desktop, logging into all the apps, all that usual stuff. And there have been a LOT of error messages that one app or another failed to load and had to close -- mostly Google Play but others as well. And it's still pretty laggy, even though all the updates and installs are done. I wouldn't recommend buying this as a primary tablet for adults to use to work on. I use a Samsung tablet for that, and it's much nicer and more responsive.

love this tablet, the battery lasts me about a week between recharges reading ebooks, the large screen makes reading so much easier than my old 6 inch tablet, it also has enough juice to play some games. It is well worth the cost for performance and screen size!

I really like this tablet...It was fairly fast and had very nice video. Sound over the speaker was not great but using ear buds was much better.  With the GPS I was using it for moving map when flying. Too bad it died after 7 months.

I have tested this tablet for almost a week now, and it is a pretty cool device. It is not a high-end

tablet, but it is well worth the price. The most novel aspect is the FM radio. Although you need to

put in headphones to use the FM (for the antenae), wi-fi does not need to be on. I tested that to confirm that it wasn't pulling internet radio. It finds local FM stations quickly and keeps them tuned in strongly.

The screen is nice and bright and videos look very good. The resolution at 800x1280 is fine for most uses (itnernet videos, some games, etc).  The speed is very nice too. Pages refresh well. The GPS (Maps app) uses wi-fi to find its way around. I was hoping to get a real satellite-based GPS instead of wi-fi, but it still works well when within wi-fi range.

The tablet is nice and light and easy to carry around. All around, a nice tablet for most purposes on the Net. I would purchase again.
Very nice tab that has powerful processor very responsive screen and the USB port Wifi all that is expected. This is the features I was looks for in my new Tab and am Happy with this.

This DOES have Dual band, which is 2.4 ghz and 5 ghz, if you cannot get 5ghz to show up, reboot your router or rename your 5 ghz wifi connection.

If this doesn't work you got a DEFECTIVE Tablet, contact the seller and get a NEW ONE.

5ghz is needed nowadays, I tested the speed difference it's at least double the speed of 2.4 ghz.

This has almost STOCK android, NOUGAT..(Android 7.0), no bloatware... which is very refreshing.
Download a different browser, I suggest firefox, it's 100X faster than chrome.

Realize Chrome is a resource HOG, you only have 1 gig of RAM, switch to firefox, NIGHT and Day difference.

Now onto some of the cons, which aren't that many, and believe me I'm tough on tablets and all electronics, but I'm REALISTIC about what I'm PAYING!

This only has 16 GB storage, 11gb after Android O.S, I tried 2 different 128 GB cards, it didn't accept them, yet I tried a 64 GB and it accepted it.

Update:**The adoptable storage on my 128GB SD card is now ruined, stopped at 20% and now my 128gb SD card is toast.

This could be a defect in the software, because it DOES detect 64 GB.

Now please be careful this tablet which I think is a great option allows you to either use as a regular sd card OR adoptable storage, now comes the problem adoptable storage once formatted for adoptable CANNOT be used ever again ONLY in that tablet.

Please be careful, if you choose to use adoptable storage use a FAST Micro SD card, also I say this because this is a $99 tablet, I don't think many people are going to spend  $40 on a FAST Micro SD!

Update*** Adoptable storage ruined my Fast 128gb SD card it corrupted it by getting stuck at 20%.

This ONLY has 1GB ram, so don't think you're going to be playing HIGH graphic games, that's not possible and not even a reasonable expectation.

UPDATE *** This is a QUAD core processor, major bug on this tablet.. It doesn't Use all the cores they go to Sleep and stay asleep.

Being there's only 1gb ram and 30%is used by Android... Loading 1 app will load to 100% capacity that's where the other cores are supposed kick in be split over the other  cores to offset the load.

So many people were  correct it will bog down after loading  1 app.
Now there is 4cores,if you Reboot a few times it will will work with the 4 cores, but if you see it working with 1 core reboot it.

This is a hardware fault, and cannot be fixed via software.

NO One should have to reboot the tablet a few times Hoping the 4 cores LOAD

This tablet had some pretty solid reviews, and at this price point, it looked like a steal. I bought two of them, because as inexpensive as they were, why not?

Unfortunately, they're CRAP. They're awful. Performance is sluggish, the display looks terrible, and the speakers make an annoying clicking sound that I'm pretty sure they're not supposed to make. And I don't think I just got a defective unit, because they both behave exactly the same way.

I bought them to replace a tablet that's a few years old and getting a bit long in the tooth, but my old tablet is so much better in every possible way -- faster performance, a vibrant, high-resolution display, and much sturdier-feeling construction -- that it's not going to be retired quite yet. The Fusion5 is just straight-up garbage in comparison.

I have no idea where all these five-star reviews are coming from, because this is an objectively terrible tablet. I don't regret giving it a shot -- you win some and you lose some when you hunt for bargains, and I lost this one. If my review spares anyone else from making the same mistake, I'll consider the whole experience worthwhile.

This is for the 16 GB, December 2017 version of the Fusion5.

I'll start with the pros before delving into my gripes. It's cheap, there's no denying that and for the price point, it's running a fairly recent version of Android (7.0 Nougat), doesn't have bloatware, is reasonably fast and for its size, feels pretty light. I also have no complaints on the battery life so far. That's all the nice things I have to say about it.

Let's start with the screen. I'm not sure if the manufacturer changed something since the reviews touting a 'crisp', 'clear' or 'amazing' display but mine is totally underwhelming to say the least. I was quite surprised and excited, unboxing the Fusion5, to see that it was an anti-glare screen (something I haven't seen mentioned in any of the reviews I've read). My excitement fizzled quickly however once the screen started showing scratches as soon as I cleaned it with a lint free cloth. I'll be honest, I knew what I was getting into with a 1280x800 resolution but be aware that with a screen that size and the resolution, you can clearly see every pixel on screen and it's often distracting, although to be fair, not so much when gaming. One last issue that has been mentioned in other reviews: it is not a bright display. In fact it's quite dim when comparing it to other tablets the same size.

Regarding the form factor, the plastic back shell feels like it could easily break. This is how it feels, I didn't either break it or attempt to break it. It just feels flimsy. Several reviews have mentioned the odd placement of the power and volume buttons and although I did get use to the buttons being placed on the top left side of the screen instead of top right, when holding the tablet in portrait mode, this inverts the up and down on the volume and I keep lowering the volume when I mean to raise it. This design decision is senseless and annoying.

I've had some problems with Bluetooth initially. It might have been an issue specific to my particular unit but I didn't seem to be able to connect Bluetooth devices that had already been paired with the tablet. It looks like it went away for now.

One final random piece of information. I purchased this tablet to run game emulators and although it will run DraStic (Nintendo DS), Mupen64 (N64), Snes9x, GemBoy!, Reicast, MAME4droid, ePSXe and PPSSPP just fine, be warned that Dolphin (GameCube & Wii) is unusable.

I'm still debating returning it.

It is very slow, looses connection and sometimes won't even turn on. When the wifi is on; it slows the tablet down so I only have it on if I am downloading or updating apps. Other than that 1 issue I am very pleased with my purchase. I would have given it 5 stars if It had better wifi performance.

When I touched to see if it was the screen protector the screen cracked the entire way across. Now the screen does not work at all. THIS TABLET WAS NOT DROPPED OR MISHANDLED, it just broke.

I contacted fusion and they discribed it as wear and tear. Completely absurd that this company considers this an acceptable failure after three weeks. Paid my money and had a poor quality tablet for three weeks. Now I am left with nothing because the company doesnt stand behind their product.

First, let me start off by saying this is not my first tablet, but this will be my last if this is the state of the tablet industry.

From the very moment that I opened the package from Amazon I knew I was going to be disappointed, and shouldn't have even bothered giving this product a chance. For starters, the tamper tape/stickers were peeled off when I first got the package, and the sticky residue was all dried up from the tape/sticker indicating that this had been peeled off long ago. Second, upon opening the box I found that my "new" tablet had finger prints all over the screen, as well as a screen protector had been improperly placed on it (air pockets, dust, and what appeared to be a bit of potato chip). There were also some minor scuffs and scratches in the plastic backing, now I don't mind the casing being plastic as that helps to keep price and weight down, but I do mind my "new" product having very obvious damage to the back.

Now, let's move to how the device performs. Slow. Simple as that, this device is so slow. It advertises 2 GP RAM and a 1.8 GHz Processor which should be able to handle almost all mobile games, so I decided to test the limits of this device with two or three different games, all of which minimum spec requirements (and even recommended) were below the specs of this device and all of the games I was averaging 11 FPS or lower, which is absolutely unacceptable to a device advertised as a gaming device. I guess I was asking for it by trying to test the hardware, but I think that a device claiming to be good for gaming should be able to at least hit 30, or even 20 Frames for a game that is far below the requirements of this device. Now, after I realized this device would be no good for gaming, I at least tried to see it's multimedia and video streaming services. Wow, was I disappointed, again, bad frame rates, and bad connection to my wireless network. After running speed tests I was averaging about 400 ms ping more on this device than any other device in my house.

All in all, do not be fooled by this product. You will probably get a used product, and your device will not perform nearly as well as it should based off the advertised spec's and hardware. Please, don't be like me and be fooled by this product.

EDIT of my EDIT: Changed the rating to five stars. After a few hours with it, and testing a few more apps out, they all handle perfectly. My unity game just has poor optimization and that's my fault. The device is a steal at the 100 dollar price point, the screen is amazing and the speakers don't suck like in other budget tabs I've bought.

EDIT: to the device's credit, I tried playing Minecraft and the experience was not terrible by any means. In fact once I played around with some settings it runs quite smoothly. Minecraft can run on a raspberry pi also so, take that how you want.

I am re-writing this review to help others when shopping for tablets....At first look I was wowed, but upon going thru set-up and configuring had to change my opinion.
This looks like a remarkable tablet by reading specs alone. I have purchased, and used many tablets, from relatively inexpensive no frills, to the big name - and big price ones. Okay, on to observations....

As others have said, the speakers sound tinny and have poor volume. Could be overcome with speakers or headphones.
Battery life will not be the best with large bright screen.
Does get quite warm on back left.
Only 16GB storage, but being Android 6, a micro SD card can be formatted as "internal" and be used for app storage.
Found it would not recognize bluetooth android controller - which works fine with my other tablets running 6.0
But the real deal killer for me is that the screen seems to be plastic. When cleaning fingerprints, it looked like this was causing the tiny fine swirls indicative of plastic.

Now to the pros....
Being full HD 1980 X 1080, the screen is sharp and clear.
Also, screen has great angles of view - doesn't fade out it tilted up / down, or left / right.
2GB ram, so there is plenty for apps
Octa-core...This tablet is fast.
No bloatware.
Android 6
10.6" - slightly wider screen than 10.1 - better for widescreen movies

Starts fast, great colors, and easy viewing. Charges with regular circular cord, so both myself and my kids (10 and under.) cannot connect it wrong - which, by the way, has killed many previous tablets. Large bright screen, has yet to crash, no bothersome bloatware, and has a protective case to match. Has micro-usb and regular usb, so can handle whatever is plugged in. I bought 3, although 1 for a spare - have kids - but despite a 600+ mile vacation trek before the start of school, tablets active all the way, no problems observed. One was dropped from about 38" while in its matching case with no damage or other issue. The third one still sits unopened in its package should any fail, I didn't want crying kids saying "why daddy!!!" Luckily, these tablets worked flawlessly, but to anyone reading, if you are on a long road trip with no WiFi or internet access, make sure that before you pull out of your driveway,set the tablets for airplane mode, and also Battery Saver. Both cell phones and tablets will exhaust their batteries trying to connect to a network that they are unable to locate while in motion. For the tablet, good dual cameras, quite clear, good resolution and recorded sound. With the protective case, output sound is a bit diminished, but a $3 headset or equally cheap set of earbuds easily compensates for the added protection. Use these with caution, as this tablet can be quite loud, but awesome with the right music. As for the seller, all arrived as expected, on time, and in a condition expected of a new device. I also appreciated the protective packaging - not tough to open, but total and solidly, safely compacted. The care taken to ensure safe arrival was obvious. Setup of the tablet was a breeze, yet boring for any IT guy, but well appreciated for its ease of use. As the owner - and purchaser of many android tablets, I have zero complaints with this one, albeit I wish I had more time to use it.
Everything works as it should.  The gps is great.

This thing is so awesome. I use it as a student for reading PDF/kindle textbooks as its way cheaper and lighter to carry around.

I haven't noticed any lagging or slowness when using it, and it arrived in 2 or 3 business days with free standard shipping.
Just all around, a good experience.

This is the first ANDROID based anything I've used that I can truly say holds up to competing systems like Windows or IOS.  The power drain usage on this thing is amazingly slow, charging is very fast.  The 2GB shows off what ANDROID (and Linux) can do with more RAM. The truly HD screen automatically sizes playback to a matching frame ratio to the video at best HD possible without any pixelation or artifacts in most instances.  I say "most" only because modern ANDROID is better at playing HD and more modern mastered Video streams, than ancient videos on retro source websites. Those play well, but do occasionally desynchronize due to the much older video technology used.  However, once you play back said videos and listen to sound, you notice rare if any pausing even when GMAIL is running or FACEBOOK is posting notifications enmasse. The system does a lot better than any other ANDROID I've seen at seamless multitasking the GUI and the Multimedia.  I've had a number of prior ANDROID products and was sorry I bought them, not to mention they wore out just outside the Warranty period.  This 10.6" Fusion5 Tablet is way better built, has extensive connectivity between its connectors and its wireless, and its keyboard works much better.  The entire tablet is FAR MORE RESPONSIVE than anything I've used previously, including a Windows Phone.  In Marshmallow (Android 6.1) Google has created a riper more mature system.  I do still wish for more control of the underlying system, but that's just because I'm a techie and I would prefer not to have to use development tools or rooting just to have access to a command shell.

However, I'd raise this Tablet's rating to 6 Stars if I could.  Nice work, Fusion 5, and "AT LAST!" to Google - keep on keeping on.

BTW, the power connector is rigidly reinforced against breakage unlike other products I've used, and the unusually long battery life insures I can run it for my entire use for at least a day, without having to recharge it.  I'm planning on acquiring a Carry Case for it and taking it on the road with me.  I do hope they produce one with a built in phone/CellModem in the future!  Nonetheless, it is an EXCEPTIONAL VALUE and an EXCEPTIONAL PRODUCT.

This tablet seemed pretty good at first: good picture, fast processor, etc. However, we've had it for about 9 months now and have repeated problems. Sometimes it just won't turn on. We'll try pushing the power button fast, slow, hold it for a while, and nothing happens. Finally, after a combination of button pushing and connecting and disconnecting the charger, it will magically turn on. This has happened several times. It will also randomly no longer recognize the data on a micro sd card or that it even has an sd card inserted. I will take it out and put it back in, but it won't recognize it. If I put the card in another device, the data is recognized, so I know it isn't the cards that are corrupt. Nonetheless, I'll have to format the sd card and re-install everything for the tablet to see it. Finally, it will occasionally not recognize that its battery needs to be charged. It will be low (anything less than 100%) and we'll go to charge it, only for it to say that it is 100% charged already when we plug it in. Since it thinks it is already charged, it won't charge it anymore, meaning we are left with little run-time before the battery goes dead. This happens a lot recently. It's too bad because I really liked this tablet at first, but it hasn't even made it a year of occasional use before going bad.

Kind of hard to nail down a completely fair review. Let me explain. I own a Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 8" which is my go to tablet. It is lightning quick, crystal clear and just an awesome tablet. It's responsiveness and build quality explain why it costs as much as it does. If I compare that tablet to this one, then I would give this one 1 star. However, when taking the price into consideration and what I wanted it for, I have to give it a few more stars. I wanted a larger (cheap) tablet that I could use and leave at work when things are slow to watch movies, play an occasional game and surf the web. So I went on a search to find a tablet that would fit those needs and not cost a lot.
I read the reviews for this tablet and considering the specs vs price I thought I may have found a diamond in the rough. Well, don't expect a Cadillac when all you pay for is a Pinto.

When I received the tablet and opened the box I immediately noticed why a tablet with such specs would be priced so low. It's all in the build. It is very cheaply made. The screen has these black lines that run across it and are really noticeable when the tablet is off. The corners of the screen were not completely glued or pressed down. At the edges of the tablet the screen looks wavy. I have what looks like a trapped air bubble under the screen in one spot. The screen shows every single finger mark, smudge mark etc. It's somewhat oddly shaped for a tablet. Seems excessively wide, too wide to sit in my bluetooth keyboard that is designed to hold tablets in the 10" (+/-) range. The power cord is short and odd. Out of the box the speakers are not loud enough. Downloading a volume booster app will fix this problem but does distort the sound to some degree. Not so much that it is an issue. This tablet looks like it would damage rather easily if dropped.

When turned on the lines on the screen are not noticeable. While viewing videos I don't notice any screen related issues. The display meets expectation. The tablet seems zippy enough and has had no issues with playing videos, a few games and surfing the web. I love the fact that it has a standard usb port as I like to use a mouse with it. I've been using it for a month or so and have not experienced any hardware related issues. I leave it plugged in while in use so I cannot comment on battery life experience. Considering the battery size (7200mAh) vs battery life other users have experienced.... battery life sucks.

Pros: It excels my expectations in responsiveness. The standard USB port is a major plus. Software doesn't feel bloated, comes with Marshmallow, cheap price. Have had zero hardware/software related issues. Good for watching movies.

Cons: all in the build. Put together really, really poorly. Feels cheap, like the smallest drop would destroy it. Looks and feels like a budget tablet.

It gets 3 stars because it meets my needs and runs well. Had it not been so cheaply put together I would have rated 5 stars for performance and price.

My last tablet was a DragonTouch x10 and I loved it, but I was ready for an upgrade to a Marshmallow tablet with a little more RAM.  This Fusion5 meets all my expectations.  Android 6, 2G ram, a beautiful screen, and all the little extras that make a tablet useful (USB, HDMI, etc). This tablet is responsive and looks great.  I am very happy!!!

I bought this to watch movies on the plane on a recent European trip and it did a great job with that. I downloaded movies from both Netflix and Amazon and it played them without any stutter. I tried to play Marvel Puzzle Quest on it but it lagged pretty slowly. So if you want something to watch movies and read books with, this would be a great choice, but it seems to struggle with games. It could really use another GB of memory and a better processor.

I think I'm going to really like this tablet. There's not much in the way of instructions that come with it, but if you're used to working with tablets in general, you won't have any problems with the Fusion5 10.6" tablet. I'm a little disappointed that the screen protective film that came with it and already installed, is so shiny. I've looked everywhere to see if I might be able to replace it with an anti-glare screen film for this particular tablet, but so far the only kind I can find are the clear shiny ones. But I might just have to learn how to hold it to reduce the glare on the screen. That is my only complaint and such a very minor one.

One other reviewer commented that this Fusion5 was "snappy." It is indeed! I love how fast it is in just about everything it can do. And I'm impressed with all the things it can do! For me, this tablet is replacing my mini-iPad and an old laptop computer which are in the process of giving up the ghost. This tablet is definitely going replace those items nicely.

I don't much like using on-screen keyboards so I'm glad that my new Fusion5 can support a Bluetooth external keyboard which I have ordered (with case), but it hasn't yet arrived so I can't let you know how well that works. But I am anticipating that it will work as well as all the other features of this tablet. And I like the fact that the tablet has an USB port for my external mouse. And that it has an SD card slot to expand the memory. Super wonderful.

So far I haven't figured out how I'm going to charge the tablet while in my car because it comes with a wall charger. It's too bad that it isn't the kind of charger that can be used either in the wall or via USB.

Connecting the tablet to my wireless in-home network was a breeze. In fact, the crazy little thing ALMOST had itself connected and had my contacts all downloaded without my help. That was a great relief because I don't like having to troubleshoot to figure out why things don't connect, which happened with other devices I've purchased.

I love all the apps that are available through Google Play! And this little tablet was fast as lightening in getting the ones I wanted to be downloaded.

I am not a technology wiz, and I'm not a paid reviewer. Just a customer who knows what they like. I give this little Fusion5 tablet an A+.

The tablet had mixed reviews, but I always tend to make my own decisions about things so took a chance and having been using the tablet for the past fifteen days I am one satisfied customer. OK, for one the item description on Amazon said that it had Android 6.0 installed on it as the operating system, BUT the tablet that I received has 5.1.1. But as a user what I want is gadget that will work predictably, stably and satisfactorily--- and it does. It charges from zero to full in about 4 hours and some minutes if I use the AC adapter that came with it and plug it into the wall directly. It takes much longer to charge if I plug it into a usb-port of my desktop, or into a standalone  6-port Poweradd usb wall-charger I purchased here on Amazon. I can also plug it into the usb-port of my kamashi 10,000 mAh power-bank I purchased on Amazon. So the charging time is fastest using the AC charger, about 4 hours and some minutes, and can be as long as 19 hours using a usb-port of a computer or a power-bank. As for the gadget-quality, its an excellent Android tablet 10.6 inches, larger than the other tablets most of which are 10.1 inches, I also purchased a case for it made by Fusion 5, and its a formidable combination since the case is tailor-made for this tablet and no adaptation is needed. I might update in the future since its been only 15 days. So here you are....:-) FYI,  I typed this review on my Fusion 5...!!!

I purchased this as a cheap add on to use with my android media center. It runs the apps I need it to run, connects them to my android tv box and works fine for my specific use.

Overall, for me, this works and I'm somewhat satisfied. I was looking for a cheap, "no frills" basic device, and that is exactly what I got.

But... if you are buying this to have as a primary general purpose tablet, you might want to spend a few more $ and get something decent. If I were to buy another, I wouldn't buy this one again.

First: it has a "cheap plastic" feel to it. I feel as though it would easily break if I handled it too rough. I would not give this to a child to use without getting a sturdy case for it.

The screen had a screen protector on it. That would be a cool "plus" except it was poorly applied and had several air bubbles in it that I couldn't get out. It annoyed me and I removed it completely. I'm hoping they didn't put it on because the screen scratches or cracks too easy. So far it hasn't happened, but certainly makes me wonder.

The power and volume buttons are not in a place where it would be natural to look for them. I find myself fumbling for them every time I turn it on. Something you can get use to, but what were they thinking?

It isn't as "fast" as other reviewers seem to think it is. I don't know what they are comparing it to, but I find it rather sluggish when opening apps, connecting to wifi and other basic task. Not an issue for my usage, but I would find it annoying if it was my primary tablet.

The camera: forget about it. I don't care how many megapixels it has, the lens on the cameras are horrible. The pictures were so blurry I though maybe I forgot to take the protective plastic shipping film off the camera lens. But nope. Just a horrible lens that can't quite focus on anything. Fortunately the camera isn't a deal breaker for my use.

The sound: yeah you can hear it. That's about it. If you want to listen to music with any kind of fidelity - you are going to need to connect to a Bluetooth speaker. The speaker in the tablet is the most basic of basic.

This isn't a high end Samsung tablet, but the price isn't that of a high end tablet either. As a first tablet or something to use for a specific purpose, you probably won't be too dissapointed. If you want a full featured quality tablet, you are going to have to spend a lot more than what this cost.

Pros: Nice big screen, bright colors, fast processors. Installed a 64Gb micro SD and its got tons of room.
Cons:
1.) AC Charger is shot at barrel connector. I tend to think this was operator error as my lady is hard on hardware, but it's a crappy design. Had it not been for my purchasing an additional USB to barrel connector I would have an nonchargeable brick.
2.) Unit DOES NOT come with a USB to barrel connector, (so be sure to buy one if you buy this).
3.) As mentioned elsewhere, it does seem to take a long time to charge. I view this as a feature, as it limits the hazard to it by the aforementioned lady who is hard on hardware.
4.) It does not come with a case, so be prepared to shell out another $15 or so for that too.
5.) It does not come with the microSD card, so be prepared to shell out even more for that.

All told I think I dropped around $150USD for it. Would I buy it again? Ask me 6 months.

So I am now ordering yet another AC adapter for the Fusion5. Seriously folks, why on Earth did you use a flimsy 2.5mm barrel adapter? These thing snaps like twigs in the wind. Being that the touchscreen is required for the thing to even function, the tablet is now junk.  I also didn't like the touchscreen when it was working. When I received the tablet, I thought it was pretty good for the price and would have given it 4 stars.  However, after 10 months, I plugged it in to charge and it would never come on again.  I contacted the company (you have to contact them through Amazon), and they were prompt in their response and had me return it.  In less than two weeks, I received another tablet, which I thought was great.  When setting up my tablet, everything was fine, but when I walked into the other room, it lost Wi-Fi signal, and when I say it lost signal, it couldn't even recognize that there was a Wi-Fi anywhere. If you stayed in the room with the router, you could get fair signal (maybe good if you wanted to stand right beside it).  I have seven other wireless devices that get good signal throughout my house.  I contacted the company again and went through a lot of things they wanted me to try, including downloading some Wi-Fi booster app from the Play Store (really??).  Of course, that didn't work and neither did the other things they wanted me to try.  So, they told me to send it back again.  It was returned to me with my Wi-Fi still saved on it, and it still functioned exactly the same.  The company said I would have to return it again with a new return slip stating the new problem since this was different than the original problem (and they couldn't have told me that before they told me to return it the second time?).  Did that, and received the same tablet back again, and the problem is still the same.  After contacting the company again, I was told that they tested the Wi-Fi and that it functioned up to 10 meters.  I can guarantee that that had to be within line of sight of the router, because it loses it when you put a wall between you and the router.  I looked up the specs for their Wi-Fi (IEEE 802.11) and it states that the typical indoor range should be about 30 meters.  Apparently, the 10 meter range is considered acceptable by this company.  Now I am out the cost of shipping this three times for nothing.  Should have applied that to the price of a different tablet.  Had my original tablet functioned like this one, I would have returned it immediately for a refund.  Buyer beware!  Worst customer service ever!

But it becomes a deal breaker when you add problem 2 in.  2- the factory preinstalled screen protector is super glare ENHANCING.  we went outside to sit on the porch during the day (in the shade) and the tablet was unusable.  I was surfing away on the nexus10 and she couldn't see a thing on the fusion5.  I tried.  I couldn't use it either.  Plus it came with bubbles in the screen like other reviewers said.  I searched high and low and could not find replacement screen protectors on amazon.  It would drive me nuts to keep the tablet and not be able to get rid of the bubbles on the screen. I'd been eyeing the Lenovo Yoga Tab 3 10.1" tablet, but I opted for the Fusion 5 based on price. I still covet the Lenovo, but I'll make do with the Fusion5 for a couple of years and see what comes down the pike later.

My main issue with the tablet is sound. It's way too quiet to watch anything with another person unless you've got a headphone splitter. I know it is not fair to compare this device to an iPad, but my girlfriend's iPad can fill a room with sound. With the Fusion5 I have to have headphones plugged in and the volume on the device and whatever video player I'm using (Netflix, YouTube, Amazon Video) turned all the way up to watch a movie or show, and even then, I need a quiet room. It's really faint.

The build quality feels flimsy, but now that I've got it in a folio case, that's not really an issue.

So why 4 stars? The screen is great. Images are absolutely gorgeous on it. Also, the 2 GB of RAM delivers flawless video playback and is really more than one can ask for at this price in March of 2017. I haven't installed any games on it, so I can't really speak to its use as a gaming device. I mainly bought it as a personal media player and as a laptop alternative when taking short trips.

I've had this tablet for over a month now. I waited to submit a review so that I could provide an accurate and thorough review.

Overall, I gave the Fusion5, 5 stars because I love it (even though there are a couple of things that are lacking). The picture is great whether I am on YouTube, Netflix, Hulu, etc, it actually came with Android 6.0, it's not too heavy. The main reason I bought this tablet was to interface with my Google apps that I use regularly (Google Drive, Google Play, Sky Maps), for reading (Amazon Kindle App), streaming music and videos.

~ I've seen many reviews stating the tablet charges slowly. I found that if I use the 5V AC charger that came with the tablet, it charges fairly quickly. If I use a micro USB charger, it takes days to get a full charge. I recommend either using the 5V AC charger that it came with or ordering another one (make sure it states 5V AC otherwise it will not work properly).

~ I saw a review or 2 saying it cut off and would not turn on. That is a simple fix, there is a reset button where the SD card slot is located, press it for a few seconds. It will make the tablet reboot. Hold it any longer than 5 seconds and you will reset your tablet.

~ The speakers really aren't that great but I have Bluetooth speakers and headphones so that really isn't an issue plus there are times when a low volume works for me, like when I am working (I talk on the phone a lot for work).

~ It does NOT have a gyroscope!

~ The only other thing I didn't like all that much is that it tells you when you connect to Wifi that it is connected but there is no internet. This is just the marshmallow version doing this as it is having trouble reaching Google's servers. You should actually be able to surf just fine and you can select the option to connect anyway.

Cannot recommend.  I will keep it and use it as a backup only.  The unit is extremely slippery and can be prone to breaking without a cover if dropped or banged. Attempted to install a Samsung Evo 32Gb Micro SD card and received a message saying it was incompatible although the card works with all my phones and other tablets runing Android 6.0 and up.  Android 6 is crippled on this machine and does not represent a good Android experience.  It is not stock Android.  I have two other tablets with less RAM and they are much more efficient in processing and an overall better experience.  There is considerable lag on this machine when using apps and the Web through Chrome. The machine is prone to freezing and turning itself off.  Overall, not happy at all with this purchase and this machine is probably OK for a kid or someone who doesn't mind its drawbacks an will use it primarily for email and perhaps some very light gaming.  Although a really budget machine, its price should be much lower considering what you get.

Yes, this device has excellent specifications for a tablet of it's price (on paper). However the posted specs do not mean much when it comes to actual performance. One example, is because the CPU has no L1 or L2 cache, multitasking is horribly slow. Actually, everything is slow. Also, the tablet is made extremely cheap. Cheap plastic (typical of items made in "that country"). However, for the price, I would keep it because it's perfectly fine for web browsing but that's really about it, but luckily that's what I mostly use it for. Now, why I will not be keeping it: The first unit I received the screen was partially detached from the body and had cracks in it. I returned it, had them exchange it, dealt with the shippers lack of Amazon Prime snail mail shipping, and then the replacement unit I had to send back because when it arrived was actually missing the power button, therefore there was no way to even turn it on. Waited for a third unit to arrive finally, and it came 2 days ago. Finally one that appeared intact, physically anyway. Excited I quickly installed all my apps and games, only to find out that none of my games work because it is impossible to control movement by moving the unit. I figured, OK, perhaps the accelerometer needs calibration. No big deal, so I do the normal procedure by moving the device in a figure 8 pattern, and install some sensor reading apps that also can calibrate it. Guess what! No accelerometer detected. That explains that! To be clear, the device is equipped with the sensor, that there is no doubt. It has to be since it's built into this model CPU! However like most things with this tablet, it's defective. So I have no way of ever playing a game on it. I suspected there might be a problem with the sensor since the screen is incapable of auto-rotating (a function that relies on the accelerometer). So, my advice after owning literally hundreds of Android phones and tablets from every manufacturer you could think of, is while it's possible I guess to get a stable unit, how long it will last is an entirely different issue, so I would strongly advise spending a bit more and getting a Samsung, LG, HTC, or another established brand. At least at a bare minimum, with the big brands, if something does go wrong, you would actually receive at least a bare minimum of support from them. Good luck!

I was on the market for a new tablet for my son for Christmas. I bought this on 12/22/16 got it just in time for him to open on Christmas. That's were the fun begins..... The tablet started out OK. I noticed that they claim that the tablet can use a 64gb SD card and also update to marshmallow Android 6.0. which was a must since you can use as card as  internal memory when using marshmallow. 16gb won't cut it especially since you really only get 12. So my tablet (the first one) wouldn't registered the card. I thought it was because it was a 64gb and it says right on the tablet expandable up to 32gb. So I tried another card I had a 32 GB card from hi previous one. Still doesn't work. So I email them tell them it's not working and I can't get Android 6.0. turns out they had to send me a card through the mail to get the software upgrade. They also assured me that 64gb will work with this tablet. So I had to wait about a week. Got the card was able to update to marshmallow. Awesome right!? Well still would read any of my cards. They then told me I had to format the SD card specifically to thier tablets standards. OK fine I do that took about 15-20mins. Still wouldn't work. So they told me to send it out and it would be fixed. They don't have a mailing label so they told me I had to pay for shipping. I told them that's not right and they told me well they can cover 10. It cost 15 to ship. Whatever. So it took about 2 weeks to receive. Keep in mind this was a Christmas gift. My son wasn't able to really use his present for almost a month through now. Got the tablet. Saw that it was not the Same tablet I sent them. There were visible lines that go horizontal on the screen that's visible when the tablet is off. And somewhat visible when on but not really. Then I noticed the SD card door adhesive was off so the door was broken. I immediately sent them an email and told them about it and they said we are sorry that shouldn't happen. Send it back to us we will cover 10 of your shipping and fix/replace it once we receive it. Are you kidding me!? Please save yourself the hassle and time. Don't order this. I understand that there are defective u it's and it happens from time to time but the way they handled it was ridiculous.

I'll start by saying that I bought this tablet because my Samsung Note 10.1 died suddenly and I wanted a 10 inch replacement to hold me over until the new Samsung Chromebooks arrived. Hopefully it will serve that purpose, at which time I can pitch it in the trash. I liked the size, memory, quad core processor, and fairly up to date OS.

After setting everything up and restoring the apps from my Samsung backup I discovered there was no way to change the display brightness. The display settings are there but they do nothing. I sent feedback to the seller and got a useless response to which I replied that there seemed to be other problems related to sensors that are present but not functioning. <crickets> In particular the magnetic sensors seem locked at one end of their range so apps that need a compass fail. I suspect that may be the reason that the newest version of Maps refuses to launch so I've had to uninstall updates and roll Maps back to the version originally installed. Of course that also means you have to turn off auto updates and deal with that stuff manually in Play. BTW, if you check under settings in Play you'll find this is not a certified system.

On the plus side, the display is nice and games play OK. Network performance is pretty good and sometimes you can get it to screencast. The latter may work more consistently with the Roku but I haven't played with that yet.

Bottom line - if you need a fully functional tablet, look elsewhere. I just hope this one holds out until I can replace it with a Samsung 2 in 1 Chromebook.

Performance is sluggish.  Switching between programs and even between tabs in the browser is very slow. Startup time is over 1.5 minutes.  And because of the awful battery life, the tablet in constantly shutting down so you have to frequently wait for the tablet to boot.

Battery life is awful.  I'm getting maybe 3 to 4 hours on a single charge.  This means that you can't use the tablet for a day without having to charge it.  So the freedom to roam around the home with the tablet is compromised  because you need to be near the charging cable.

Audio - it is a disgrace how bad the audio is.  Very tinny. The max volume is not louder than a whisper.  Really, this is the best that they could do?

I've been tempted many times to return this tablet. But It is cheap and therefore I'm willing to keep it with all its blemishes. But I would not buy another one, that's for sure.

 When it finally decides to work, it has good speed and a good picture. Can't say I recommend it.

Not only did I have the problem I listed below, but tonight the screen of the "good" tablet cracked in three long lines all the way across the display. The kicker is that it wasn't dropped or abused. I have asked Fusion5 to help me with this - their warranty says they won't fix damage done by the buyer - but if  the tiny hand of an 8 year old can crack the screen while just holding it in his hands - they really need to help me out with this. The one I bought had European and US charger. The one my aunt sent had only US charger. They both start up the same way with the same splash screen. The one bought for me is extremely slow. It constantly behaves as if I am touching it all over the screen even if I am not touching it at all. The calibration of the touch screen when I *DO* touch it is completely wrong.

I can't believe the same listing for the same product could produce two such Dramatically different behaving devices. So I can't rate this well at all. I'm very upset and I haven't got the heart to tell my aunt the one she sent me is such garbage. :(

I purchased two Fusion5 108 tablets as early Christmas presents for my wife & I; they arrived promptly and in undamaged condition.  I've been using my tablet for about a week now, & overall I'm quite satisfied with my purchase; the display is bright & clear, and the processor seems sufficiently fast & responsive.  There are a few issues, however, that are not so great IMO:

1. When the screen turns on, there's an audible "snap" sound and sometimes a little flash; this makes me concerned for the long-term durability of the display panel (I checked to ensure the device's interface sounds were turned off in case this was a design feature). (UPDATE 02/08/2017: This problem seems to have largely gone away -- possibly the unit just needed a break-in period to resolve itself.)

2. The tablet seems to have some difficulty in maintaining WiFi connections; I connect to a local Xfinity hotspot at work, & while my phone (A Samsung S5) has no trouble staying connected, I find I sometimes need to reconnect my tablet a couple times per day. (UPDATE 02/08/2017: This issue now seems to have resolved itself; I don't drop connections anymore.)

3. The bluetooth connection to my wireless headphones (MPOW Cheetahs) is strong & clear most of the time, but sometimes suffers from an annoying "stutter" that goes away if I reconnect the headphones and/or reboot the tablet.  I'm not sure if that's a limitation of the tablet's internal Bluetooth stack or the Android Lollipop OS, or something else entirely. (UPDATE 02/08/2017: This issue seems to have resolved itself; I no longer have have any connectivity or playback issues with Bluetooth -- possibly the unit just needed a break-in period.)

4. Finally, and for me this is the most irritating issue, when using the tablet in portrait mode, sometimes the display refuses to register touch input (particularly in the case of pop-up windows), forcing me to turn it 90 degrees to landscape before it will accept my input.

(UPDATE 02/08/2017: This sometimes happens in landscape mode as well, & the fix is the same -- turn it 90 degrees & hope the spot you want to click will respond now.  Now that I've had a couple months to use it, it appears there may be a full or partial touch-sensor "dead zone" somewhere in the middle of the display. For example, I play the game Fallout Shelter quite a lot lately, and one of the main activities is dragging people from one room to another; very often I'll lose connection to who I'm moving while dragging them across the middle of the screen, & the only way I've found around it so far is to move my view around enough to where I can drag a person without having to cross the "dead zone".  I clean the display regularly but have had no success in clearing this up on my own.  The tablet did come with a screen protector pre-installed; I suppose it's possible it could be blocking or dampening the capacitive response, but I'm hesitant to try removing it -- the screen is only standard glass vs. Corning Gorilla Glass or the like so I don't want to render it any more vulnerable, plus I'm concerned I may end up damaging the screen myself in the process of removing the protector.)

None of these are deal-breakers for me (I can't expect Samsung or Apple performance from a $130 tablet after all), but they are still annoying.  In the end though, I can certainly recommend this tablet for an enjoyable experience that won't break your bank!

(UPDATE 02/08/2017: I've tried contacting Fusion5 support through their website several times now to address the touch-sensor issue, and as of yet I've heard no response, not even a canned "we've received your message" reply to let me know I'm not just shouting into the void.  That's rather disappointing for a company that touts its customer service as a selling point.)

My new Fusion5 was working perfectly 'til one day I put it on the charger at 23% for two hours--it went black and wouldn't boot.  After repeated tries, I emailed Fusion5 through Amazon, they replied immediately and sent a form with instructions to mail for service, but I had thrown away the shipping box and was looking for another.  I made one last try and saw a fleeting view of an empty battery so, hoping for the best, I plugged it in.  It is now working perfectly as the amazing tablet others say it is.  The same day my Blu Vivo XL (Type C, different room) went black on the charger and would't boot.  Luckily, I found a new T-Mobile store where a nice young man worked on it 'til he finally saw a glimmer of a battery and it began charging, so I took it home and it's now working perfectly too.

Then I saw an electrician in my building and asked him about power fluctuations.  "Remember," he said, "all the bottom plugs are for lamps and turn on and off at the switch."  Mystery solved!  Who knew?  It wasn't Fusion5 or BLU at all, and it's possible that can help some others in apartment buildings too.

I tried resetting back to the factory setup a couple of times with and without the sd card but it didn't help. Another problem was with the audio. Although the audio was nice and clear, the volume level was very low. I also found out that it had changed my sd card from 32 gig to 16 gig. I was able to clear the partitioning on my Windows PC and re-partition it back to 32 gigs. As much as I would loved to have had this tablet work correctly, I had to return it for a refund.

**Update** After having had this tablet for nearly 4 months I thought an update review was in order. Tablet is still in great working order. I have had zero issues and have learned a few new helpful things about it. Firstly I can confirm this tablet will accept and utilize a 128gb SD card. I have also learned that you can enhance battery life significantly without affecting performance by using battery saver function. I have been using this function and have not noticed any slowdown in performance at all. You can enable this function by going to settings\battery top right side a drop down menu battery saver. This will bring up the menu where you can enable it. By using this you are looking at over an hour extra extended battery life possibly more depending on what you are doing. This is definitely worth looking in to.

So: I've been using Android tablets for a couple of years now - maybe three years. Always budget-class. It was time to go up a notch, jumping in price by $40 to $50. That got me double the RAM (this device, 2 GB) and the superior display technology. Also, this unit sports a rare feature: a real (full-size) USB 2.0 port that you'll never find on a cheapo model. The battery, while still not user-replaceable the way I'd like it to be (good luck finding that), at least is a whole lot bigger than my old ones.

I have had this one about a week. Initially I worked with it all day to set it up like my last tablet. It performed very well. Installing my long list of favorite apps, fiddling with a lot of settings, getting the font to look big enough, etc. - all of it went like buttah.

Then I got to the copying of my old files, which I had put onto a stick drive for the occasion. TILT!!!! Inserting the stick drive into that full-size USB port caused the device to simply konk out. *Immediately.* Total blackness. And it refused to reboot. Panic... I hunted and hunted for a "reset hole" - you know, where you poke with a paper clip. NOT. There isn't one. Or it's so hidden it escaped me. I looked for quite some time, even behind the trapdoor which hides the SD card slot.

The booklet in the box was of no help. It explains a little about using Android, but nothing much about the tablet itself. I phoned Amazon - no tech help there, but we arranged a return & refund.

Thus I was very close to sending the thing back. Just then I tried to boot it up again - an hour after the problem began - and it worked. So I'm keeping it unless the glitch repeats. So far so good.

The superior screen is dazzling, very sharp, with good colors and the advertised viewing angle. The 2 GB RAM just zips along. I did get to copy all those old files using the full-size USB port. That went swimmingly - so fast I was really impressed. The bigger battery gives me lengthy times between charges.

Overall, summarizing: it's fast, the screen's excellent, great battery capacity. But... there was that bad glitch w/the full-size USB port. The 'instruction' booklet is so generic it's useless. And there's no reset thingie (as far as I know).

BTW I don't think I'll be trying the cameras, but the one on the back looks pretty respectable w/5 megapixels & some kind of zoom... a good selling point for some people.

First off, I'm gonna use my tablet for Multimedia. That is its sole purpose. Watching videos, movies and playing games.

Now, I've actually done extensive research online by watching youtube reviews of all different tablets from $49-$300, meticulously reading almost all 163 reviews of this tablet and countless others on the different tablets Amazon,BestBuy,Walmart and Ebay(to name a few) sells. I've been looking up this info for about 1 week now nonstop!

These are my findings and I hope it helps someone else:

PROS:
1. It's very snappy and speedy thanks to the 2GB RAM.
This runs KODI perfectly and flawlessly. It runs it better than my PC! Also, it runs any game I've thrown at it perfectly. There's no lag whatsoever.
2. Screen quality is awesome. Period.
It looks crisp and clear at 1366x768. It has great viewing angles w/ no "burn-out" on screen. Colors are very vivid. That's one of the reasons I decided on this one. It's the only one w/ this resolution at this price and let's face it, 90% of the tablet is going to be the screen.
3. For this price point, I think you're gonna have a hard time finding a better tablet. Let's dare to compare, shall we?
This tablet is almost on par with the Samsung Tab A! Same 2GB/16GB storage, they both use an octa-core processor. Only differences I can see is Sammy has 1920x1200 res,Touchwiz ui and its 10.1" whereas this one is 10.6". Price for this one-I paid $99.97 and Samsung is $197.
I picked Samsung b/c right now they're one of the best Android manufacturers.
4. The build quality is awesome, too.
Even though it is made out of plastic, I don't think it looks cheap at all. I think it's smexy. Guess who else makes their products out of plastic? Ans:Samsung! This one even comes with a screen protector already on it.
5. There's lots of ports.
It has mini HDMI, full size USB port, Micro sd card slot, Micro USB port and a DC port. What could you do w/ all them ports? Wellll...First thing I thought about was hooking up an usb hub to the full size usb port then plugging up a keyboard and mouse. Next, add an external hard drive and charge it with the DC cord. Hehehe. I'm not going to do that but it was fun thinking about the possibilities!

CONS:
I think they are very minor w/ easy fixes but I felt like they needed to be said. And please remember that this tablet, I guarantee, is the best you're gonna get for this price (which means they had to compromise in some areas to keep it at this price)

1. Speakers are ridiculously low!
I read the other reviews that also said the speakers were bad and I thought they must be exaggerating (sorry for doubting you guys) They are not!! One way I fixed the issue is I downloaded an app from Google Playstore named SpeakerBoost. Its free. That seemed to help. Also, KODI allows you to amplify the audio among other things while you're using it and that's what I use mainly for my media.
2. Battery lasts about 5 hrs w/ it being constantly on and screen brightness is ~40%.
This is my 1st tablet so I don't know if that's good or bad or what. Again, I downloaded a couple of apps on the Google Playstore. Their names are: DU Battery Saver, DS Battery Saver and Greenify. They all are also free. That really seems to have helped.
3. Back cover is a fingerprint magnet and it's a little slippery but a cheap case will fix that.
4.$!@#%-LolliPop! Do I need to say anything else?!
Even though it's running almost vanilla android, you cannot move any apps to the sdcard at all, but you do get a little over 12GB out of the box so thats nice. I did notice that in settings, you could check for "FOTG" updates so maybe it will get Marshmallow?

Supplemental Info:
I ran some benchmarks.
Antutu score: it was almost 29000.
CPUz: it confirmed all the specs that are on the product.

All in All, this tablet is perfect for me and it honestly beat my expectations. I don't think the pictures do it justice! I would recommend this tablet to anyone and at this price, it's a steal!

One last thing. I bought this tablet from FUSION5 on Tue. Nov. 22nd w/ free super-saver shipping and it was delivered today at 11:23am! That's unbelievable! Did I mention that I LOVE THIS TABLET!!

UPDATE: 122516
I still love my tablet. Its perfect for me and I would buy it again. With that said, 2 issues have arisen. Not deal breakers by no means but I feel they need to be mentioned. They are:
1. As some other reviewers have reported, the screen flickers sometimes. You really notice it when the background is white. If you turn the screen off then back on after about a minute, it goes away. Personally, it doesn't bother me in the least.
2. Also, everytime you turn the screen on, you hear an audible clicking sound. I have no clue as to what it could be. It doesn't effect the tablets use in any way, though.

One thing to note,as my experience, is that whatever version your tablet comes with, thats what its gonna have FOREVER (as one commented earlier, my version was Lollipop and it still is but if you look at the product desc. it ships with Marshmallow now).I paid just $99 cuz it was around Black Friday but even at the current price, I would totally be willing to buy it again-especially now that there is a Full HD version for a couple of bucks more!

I purchased the Fusion5 10.6" 108 OctaCore tablet last week from Amazon Prime, arrived in two days. I also ordered the matching Fusion5 case and I'm quite impressed so far, the case is custom made for this tablet and is worth the price. The large 10.6" IPS screen is clear, crisp and bright, the screen responds well to touch and feels just right. The ample 2gb of DDR3 RAM  along with the 8 core CPU really make this tablet quick and responsive. I added a 64gb SD card and have no problem moving data to the storage card. I really love the full size USB port, very handy for moving videos and photos to the tablet from my Macbook Pro.
Videos play very smooth and the wide screen format is really nice for viewing 16:9 format. It's not loaded with bloatware, which seems to be the norm with many tablets or phones. The images on the cameras are decent. Battery life is pretty good, granted it's not 10 hours like my wife's ipad4 Retina but it's a solid 5 hours plus currently. Android 5 Lollipop is a solid OS and is easy to use, actually a bit more user friendly than the version 5 I have on my phone.
This tablet has two speakers both on the back of the tablet and have decent volume. The Fusion5 108 matching case has slots for the speakers so they don't get drowned out by having it in the case plus openings for the cameras and all ports and buttons. I would prefer the speakers forward facing, something few tablet manufacturers do and there certainly seems to have room around the display bezel to incorporate front loaded speakers.
Bluetooth works fine with my wireless headphones. I haven't yet tried the HDMI port yet but I've got a four day Labor Day holiday break starting tomorrow and I'm anxious to see how well the HDMI output looks on my 50" UHD 4k TV. Play store downloads are fast on my home wifi , Youtube videos also start very quick, only a few videos I've watched have had any buffering delay, even then it's just a slight pause. It has the standard Android web browser and Google Chrome is pre-loaded.
I downloaded and ran AnTuTu bench marking software and the tablet scored around 25,000 on the test.
Overall, I think this is a very good tablet for the money, I would love to have had the option to choose a Fusion5 108 with a Retina type display, having said that, the 1366  x 768 is a very nice display with no stuck pixels and quite sharp edge to edge.

My needs from an Android tablet weren't elaborate to begin with, so my positive review may not be valuable to some. Basically, I wanted something I could do simple web and communication stuff with, that would run Lollipop or better (with updates permitted) without being slow to boot, wake, switch apps, etc. and without having to recharge frequently. This does all that, with additional benefit of being a larger screen than I needed, but lightweight enough that the size isn't awkward.

That light weight, and the plastic case, might work together to give some people a feeling that the device is flimsy. I can, unfortunately, testify that it's actually very sturdy because I drove off the other morning with it resting on the roof of my car, from which it naturally flew off. A stranger, out walking his dog not too far from my home, found it with the back plate popped off, the buttons missing and the display apparently extensively scratched. But he snapped the plate back on, operated the side switches with a screwdriver, and found my info to contact me and return it. All the front scratching happened to the screen protector film that the manufacturer kindly included; when I peeled it back the display itself is still perfect. So the only damage is a bit of scuffing around the edges of the back plate -- and the loss of the buttons, which I'm thinking of taking up a s 3-D printing project. Otherwise, the device still works as well as ever.

The only criticism I might make of the plastic case is that I really don't like the super-polished finish. It just begs for fingerprints and other smudges (and, for that matter, scuffing) and is a style that looked unnecessarily cheap when it first appeared maybe a decade ago and now looks unnecessarily dated. It's not worth turning down what is otherwise a great product, especially for the price, but the manufacturer might consider something matte.

The included pin-port charger is an awkward cube shape, into which the plug tines won't retract or fold (though they can be popped off because they are one of a set included for different outlet standards) so both carrying it around and storing it aren't as easy as might be hoped. But since the device can also be charged by any standard USB charger, that's a minor critique too.

I write this evaluation with the disclaimer that I am new to the tablet world.
I spent hours reviewing tablets and considering exactly what I wanted the tablet to do.  The primary function was to replace my laptop on travels to and from 2 different residences on the weekend.  I was looking for a unit that had ample viewing area (i.e. screen size for older, used eyes), sufficient memory (upgrade to more storage space), internet access in the form of pairing with my Galaxy phone (my internet source for the second residence), size and price.  The options available are overwhelming and the reviews are plentiful enough to give one a sense that the options available far exceeded my needs.
I chose the FUSION5 based on the screen size, processor, and overall appearance.  The last and certainly not the least of my considerations was the cost.  It is a parallel support instrument for travels and convenience, not a work horse and this final consideration drove my purchase of the tablet.
First and foremost, the quality is exceptional.  The screen is of ample size and clarity.  The ease of use (at the time of this review) in navigating the system has not been overly challenging.  Time and use will determine how the unit truly rises too or falls away from the intended use.  That being said, I am quite happy with the form and function, the cost, appearance and size.
