I absolutely LOVE this tablet. The screen is large and clear, and extremely bright. I previously had a cheap-o Polaroid Android tablet that I bought here on Amazon, but I had to return it because it wouldn't properly charge the battery. It would only add about 1% to the battery charge per hour, so that made it useless. Upon returning the Polaroid, I started shopping for another tablet. One of the problems I had with the Polaroid $70 tablet was that the screen was not very bright. I go to kidney dialysis three days a week, five hours a day, in a very brightly lit dialysis center, so having a screen that is bright and can cut through the glare from the fluorescent overhead lights was critical.

There are a bunch of no-name tablets out there at cheap prices, but in reading about "brands" when it comes to tablets, Fusion5 kept coming up over and over again. So I narrowed down my choices and the Fusion5 108 Octa Core tablet just kept coming up on the top of my list, over and over again. Despite there being cheaper alternatives, I paid the slightly higher price and jumped in with both feet. I'm sure glad I did.

The tablet absolutely DELIVERS when it comes to the display: crisp, bright, bold, sharp and very, very easy on my eyes. Plus it boots up very quickly as compared to the Polaroid tablet (probably 3-4X faster to get from power off to the desktop). In addition, the latest version of the Google Play Store was already installed, which WASN'T true with the Polaroid tablet. I had to jump through about 45 minutes worth of hoops to get the new version of Google Play installed on the Polaroid tablet before I could use the Google Play Store, because it would crash every time otherwise. With the Fusion5, Google Play's latest version was installed and ready to go -- so no messing around with downloading the APK and installing the new version.

This Fusion5 tablet feels really good in my hands. It is a little heavy, but not overly so, and I've ordered a nice tablet folio cover/stand to use it for viewing on my lap while in the dialysis chair. That will make things work nicely, but be warned: because this tablet is a 10.6" wide-screen tablet, I didn't find a lot of choices for folio covers. A sleeve is not what I wanted, I needed something that would work as a stand as well. Many choices in an inexpensive universal folio cover/stand for 10.1" tablets but very few for 10.6" tablets like this one.

Finally, my one major criticism: the micro SD card slot is a total pain to use. It is hidden behind a removable "door" and it requires that the person inserting or removing the micro SD card have some fingernails. The access area is so tiny and so constricted, I had to use a magnifying glass to determine exactly how to insert the micro SD card that I have (a 64 GB SanDisk micro SD). I was able to have my daughter insert the micro SD card for me. This was going to be a problem for me, because I store a lot of things on the micro SD by putting it into my laptop then inserting it into the tablet. In and out on a regular basis wouldn't work well because of how this device has the micro SD port physically configured. Instead, because this tablet has a regular-sized USB port, I went ahead and got a 64GB thumb drive... that makes it easy to transfer stuff to and from my laptop and the tablet. Now I just leave the micro SD card in place.

I would definitely recommend the 10.6" Fusion5 108 Octa Core Android tablet.

When looking for a tablet I use some version of this mental equation, Buy if Price + Features meets your needs. This tablet definitely met my features and price requirements. I love the 2GB ram. My main use is to watch videos and browse web pages. For the price, you can't beat the speed of the processors and the hardware it comes with. I highly recommend it. I've bought $800+ fully loaded iPads before and this thing beats them hands down.
It's a little rough around the edges though. The basic Android battery meter was not showing the correct battery levels initially so I had to reset it manually by discharging and charging the unit a couple of times. The volume and screen contrast levels are a little weak. The speaker holes are rear facing so for optimum sound you need a stand that doesn't block its backside.
The charging plug is a small cylindrical plug (not a micro USB) and the AC adapter is a one piece unit so if it fails I would have to go looking for this special AC adapter. I wish the cable for the power plug came with a standard USB on one end and their round plug on the other. That would make it very easy to swap adapters. I'm not criticizing the choice of the round plug, in fact I think it's better than the micro USB charging ports because they tend to get loose or sometimes get totally destroyed by frequent use. This has happened to me on a cell phone and another Android tablet in the past and there is almost no way to fix that problem but to replace the unit entirely when the micro USB receptacle gets mangled.
With a full charge, it seems to stream videos for well over 4-5 hours continuously.
Every once in a while the tablet freezes or needs a reboot. I'm not sure if it's Android or the tablet.
However, in spite of the rough edges, I think it's still a pretty good deal at $149 delivered. I don't really need to worry about it being dropped kicked, stolen, immersed in soda, abused by kids, etc. I'll just get another one and I'm pretty sure the newer versions will have some of the rough edges smoothed out. I've found over time that generally people tend to baby expensive electronics and limit their use of it in fear of it getting damaged or lost. So it's nice to have a tablet that performs well but you didn't shell out so much money for it that you don't hesitate to use it as much as possible for your own convenience. It's weird but it's along the same line of thinking as plastic sofa covers back in the 70s...who liked them? But plenty of people bought them for their sofas. My thinking is : then why buy a nice sofa?

There is no OTA update for 6.0.  I have emailed customer support asking about it.  So I have to remove apps to install others (16 gig fills up very fast).

Otherwise this has been a nice tablet.

The tablet seemed sensational, I downloaded several of my favorite apps which I use on an I-pad.  They performed well.  The second day, the tablet would not turn fully on.  The screen would light up with the logo "Fusion5" for ~ 10 seconds, then go dark for ~ 10 seconds.  It just cycled through the 2 states endlessly, it would not turn off either.  When I put it in the return box, it was still cycling off and on.

This is easily the fastest Android tablet I've purchased to date. My old tablet was driving me crazy with lags in performance, and the more apps I installed, the more lags I'd have to contend with. The Fusion5 has all but eliminated the lags. I haven't installed a lot of apps on it so far, but each app I've installed so far hasn't caused a slow-down. I haven't added extra memory yet, so it's doing well on the internal 16 gb. Can't say how it works hooking it up with the TV since I've yet to do that, but the resolution of the tablet's screen is a fine resolution without any distortion while viewing it at an angle. I'll have to say I'm impressed with this tablet. If I encounter any issues with it, I'll report back here.

6-28-2016:
One thing I noticed is that when I added a Micro SD card to bump up the memory, I don't have an option to move installed apps to the extra memory. In my other Android devices, there's a button that you can tap in the Apps section in Settings to move apps to the SD card, but this device doesn't have that button. So you can store data on an SD, but not apps. This is not a deal breaker for me because the internal 16 GB of memory is enough for me for installing apps, but it might be for some people.

I've been using this tablet for about a month now and so far so good. It is as fast as any I have had and very responsive. The screen is not AWESOME, but it is more than adequate. I enjoy using my Fusion5 104 very much. (To people who say "Get a Samsung: I've had 2 Samsung tablets and two phones, and I am NOT impressed.)

I am a fairly heavy user and I have to say, the battery life has been surprisingly good. I can use the tablet most all day without it going flat. It is fairly slow to charge but also slow to discharge, so that's a wash.

As to reviewers who complain about customer service: I had a couple or three issues while setting up, and each of my questions was answered within just a few minutes.  !!!  One problem I had was that the screen calibration was a bit off. I emailed Fusion through the Amazon Marketplace and "Lillian" responded almost immediately and said to do a factory reset to solve this. I did, and now the screen is dead on. WooHoo!

My only real complaint is not with the tablet but with the Fusion5 branded leather look protective case. When I inserted the tablet into the case so that 1) the camera lenses match the case holes, and 2) the case opens book style (right to left) as I think it should, and even 3) the buttons and jacks are accessible, then the buttons and jacks are on the bottom of the tablet rather than on top as I would expect them to be. I'm getting used to that and it hasn't been a problem in the past couple of weeks.

Oh and one other thing... The device info on Amazon says the tablet has two USB ports. Mine has only one. Don't know if this is a newer model or what, but I was a little disappointed. Haven't needed two ports yet, but one never knows, does one? I do like the USB dongle that came in the box. I've used it with a couple of my thumb drives with good results.

Overall, I'd buy this Fusion5 104 tablet again for the same money.

Flexible and Snappy Android Tablet.  I have been working on this tablet for a while now.  It is running lollipop 5.1 and is snappy.  Applications launch quickly. I love this tablet.  It is so much better than my previous tablet in almost every aspect.

First of all, it's big, 10 inches.  My previous tablet was only 7 inches. Some of you may think that it's only 3 inches different, but
when it comes down to square inches, it's practically twice the size (32 inches squared vs 73 inches squared).

Secondly, there's the speed.  The Fusion5 108 has 8 cores and is 1.8Ghz.  So far, I haven't had any lag.  I can have several apps running and play games with no problems.

Third, is the RAM.  Most tablets have only 1GB of RAM, but this tablet has 2 GB, which makes a huge difference.

Fourth are the cameras, 2 megapixels and 5 megapixels.  They are adequate quality, but I wouldn't bother taking any family photos with them.

The battery is 7200 mah, which should last you about 5-6 hours of gaming.

I haven't had a chance to try the HDMI yet.

The bluetooth and wifi work just fine.  For the record, it doesn't have GPS.

The touch sensitivity is...good.  There are times when I have to tap on the screen twice, but I think I can get used to it.

This is the case that I got for it:
http://www.amazon.com/Fintie-Dragon-Touch-KingPad-K100/dp/B013WC6TL6/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1463891236&sr=8-2&keywords=kingpad+k100

The Kingpad K100 has the same dimensions as the Fusion5 108, so it fits fine, but it's NOT prefect.  The case covers the speakers.

Another problem are speakers.  They're not very loud and average quality.  Plus, they're on the back of the tablet, so they're being directed away from you.

Overall, I'm very satisfied with this tablet and I would definitely recommend it to my friends.

PS: one thing that I am concerned about is the battery life.  My previous tablet only lasted about 5 months before it stopped charging and I had to send it in 3 times before the warranty expired.  I'll post an update for this in 6 months.

This product was provided at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

Update 09-13-16:  Well, like my previous tablet ASUS ME170CX, this Fusion5 tablet stopped charging.  Don't get me wrong, I love this tablet, it's great.  However, I had to send it back in to get it replaced or repaired.  I'm waiting to hear back from them.

It has 16 gb of storage and an expandable memory slot so space isn't an issue at all. WIFI works well with my home and work networks. I can watch Netflix or listen to Pandora without issue. I use bluetooth headphones and bluetooth speakers with it and they have worked perfectly. This tablet does everything I want it to do, it does it fast and so far with no hiccups at all. It has a solid feel to it and a great price. I would highly recommend this tablet to anyone looking for a quality tablet at an affordable price. I bought this specifically for GPS navigation.  Google Drive and other navigation apps don't work offline.  Google Drive only works if you download maps for the area ahead of time while connected to WiFi, and the maps expire in 29 days.  Downloaded maps include an area from about Philadelphia to Richmond.  You must download maps without gaps between maps, or driving directions won't work.  Apparently the apps are intended for smartphones, which are constantly online via cell phone towers.  Also downloading can't be done with slow
WiFi, as in most motels, so download your maps before beginning a trip.  Traffic information is available only while online.  I found it useful as a supplement to a dedicated GPS system such as Tom-Tom.  Google drives gives the advantage of having live maps while driving, so you can pick the best route between the choices of the two units.

As a software developer and I/T specialist for over 20 years, this is actually my first tablet purchase, and I selected this particular unit based primarily on other Amazon reviewers.  I've been using this in a casual manner daily for the last month, and have not had a single technical issue.  My primary use for this is streaming video, so I was very happy to see that Netflix and Amazon Video were working well after a couple of app downloads and within a few minutes.  The wireless connections are stable, video content streams without interruption, and web browsing performance is very acceptable.

Initially, I thought I had a hardware issue with the headphone jack as none of my headphones would fully seat all the way into the jack.  I was one step away from calling support, when I decided to push my luck and really make an effort to make the headphones seat all the way in.  Sure enough, with just a little more pushing, the headphones snapped into place with a satisfying "click".  I've never used a device where it took that extra bit of effort to seat the headphones, but I can say I love that!  I have had the jack loosen and wear on too many other devices, and I feel this unit is rock solid in that regard.

From a performance standpoint, this tablet has met my expectations.  I really had a concern about buying a tablet with only 1GB RAM given that my primary purpose is watching movies, but that hasn't been a problem at all, and the CPU specifications seem to fit well with my typical usage.  I do notice some activities / apps seem a little more sluggish than what I am used to on a laptop or PC, but that is to be expected.  Battery consumption on this device seems to be really hit and miss.  I can watch 1-2 hours of video and not really take a hit, but letting the laptop sit idle or 1/2 hour of internet browsing can suck the battery life.  Not sure if background/system activity is the primary drain, but I feel like I need this plugged in more often than I should based on my usage and past experience with other battery-reliant devices.  The charging speed on this unit seems a little slower than I would expect, even though I have a dedicated "smart" USB 4A-capable charging outlet.

Even though this is a non-US based company, the fact that they have a service presence in the US gave me piece of mind that if something was wrong, I wouldn't have to deal with international considerations getting it resolved.  That played a significant part in my purchase as well.

I have used laptops for the last 15 years for my personal and business needs.  I'm not sure that this tablet (or any other, for that matter), could ever replace my laptop based on my current usage.  However, this device is an excellent, portable complement to my laptop without lugging around the weight of a laptop.  I did purchase an additional micro-SD 64GB storage disk that allows me to store quite a bit of media files for this tablet, and that has been working out great, minimizing the reliance on the laptop. I prefer to leave the internal 32GB to the operating system and app installations as much as possible, so the additional 64GB "external" storage is helpful.

It was a little challenging finding a tablet with these specifications at this price point and a good reputation, so after a month's worth of use, I came out ahead on this purchase. This is the first tablet I would recommend to friends and family.

I bought this tablet to replace my aging Sony Tablet S.  I consider myself a fairly high tech person - I make my living with computers, and I have even worked a bit on coding apps for Android.  I cannot complain about this tablet.  It has some shortcomings, but with a price of under $150 they can be overlooked.  The tablet just works. It is fast, and it is up to date.  I have watched Netflix on it, as well as installed and ran several games.  It seems I have access to everything on the Android marketplace.  WIFI works well with both my home and work wireless, Bluetooth connection to my Bluetooth headphones worked flawlessly.  The speakers do sound a bit flat, as well as not being terribly loud, but use some headphones and the problem is fixed. Battery life has lasted for an hour or two I was off the charger, which is about the maximum I used the tablet in a sitting.

Build is good.  The shell is plastic, but but the tablet feels good in the hand. I am not sure it would take a lot of abuse, but an adult who does not mistreat it should not have any issues. All buttons are on one of the short edges, with the front and read cameras being on the same end of the tablet.  Both cameras are near one corner, so you should not have any issues with placing your had over the cameras.

The tablet is supplied with an OTG (On The Go) cable which will allow you to hook up USB thumb drives and other USB  devices up to the tablet. When this cable is in use you cannot charge the tablet as the same slot is used for both.  It is nice they supply the OTG cable with the tablet.

At under $150 this tablet is jam packed full of power and features I did not think were available at this price.

I really wanted to love this tablet. It's wonderfully done. But the one Fatal Flaw is that it's impossible to insert the SD Card into the slot. And then, if you do, it can NEVER be taken out again. If using SD storage is important to you, then this tablet is off limits. Also, the web site listing states:  " Further storage can also be added via a micro SD card (Supports upto a 128-gb TF-card) (not included)."  But the protective screen cover on the tablet clearly says "32 GB" only. So it's highly limited and then you can't change the card once it's inserted. Such a shame. It's a wonderful tablet otherwise. For someone who works online all the time, this is not a factor. But for me, who plays recorded movies a lot, it's a deal breaker. It's too bad the web listing LIED . . .  How could the manufacturer include such a horrible SD slot???  I purchased an eyeglass screwdriver to seat the SD card . . . It was long enough, but I still couldn't get the card to be seated and recognized.
And . . . Oh yes, I'm a computer techie and still couldn't figure it out!

One More Thing:  The power adapter has a tiny round connection. Looks like a toy thing. If the flimsy connector breaks (only a matter of time), you can't just use a standard micro usb cable. You'll spend weeks trying to order a new power adapter. I don't think you can just replace the cable. You need to get the whole adapter with cable attached.
